name: Uttapam
history: Uttapam is a South Indian dish similar to a pancake or dosa. It is a popular breakfast item, traditionally made with a fermented batter of rice and urad dal.
description: Uttapam is a thick pancake, with toppings like tomatoes, onions, capsicums, and green chilies cooked right into the batter. It is usually served with a variety of chutneys and sambar.

instructions.title: Prepare the Batter
instructions.description: Soak the parboiled rice, urad dal, and fenugreek seeds in water for at least 6 hours or overnight. Drain and grind them into a smooth batter using a blender or grinder, adding water as needed. The consistency should be slightly thick. Transfer the batter to a large mixing bowl, cover, and let it ferment in a warm place for 8-10 hours or until it doubles in size.

instructions.title: Prepare the Toppings
instructions.description: Finely chop the onions, tomatoes, green chilies, capsicum, and coriander leaves. Set aside to use as toppings for the uttapam.

instructions.title: Make the Uttapam
instructions.description: Heat a griddle or tawa over medium heat. Lightly oil the surface. Pour a ladleful of the fermented batter onto the griddle and gently spread it to form a thick pancake. Do not spread it too thin.

instructions.title: Add Toppings
instructions.description: Sprinkle a portion of the chopped onions, tomatoes, green chilies, capsicum, and coriander leaves over the top of the uttapam. Press them lightly into the batter. Drizzle a little oil around the edges.

instructions.title: Cook the Uttapam
instructions.description: Cook the uttapam until the bottom turns golden brown and crispy. Flip it carefully and cook for an additional 1-2 minutes, allowing the toppings to get slightly cooked.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the uttapam hot with coconut chutney or sambar. Repeat with the remaining batter and toppings to make more uttapams.

tips: Ensure the batter is fermented well for the best texture and taste.
Vary the toppings according to your preference for different flavors.
variations: Add grated carrots or beetroot for a nutritious twist.
Experiment with different chutneys like mint or tamarind for variety.

storage.shelfLife: Batter can be refrigerated for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Store the batter in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

reheatingInstructions.instruction: Reheat the uttapam on a hot griddle for a few minutes until warm and crispy.

presentationTips: Serve on a traditional banana leaf for an authentic South Indian experience.
Garnish with a wedge of lime and a sprinkle of fresh coriander.
